qas.question: What do all genes contain that is required for their expression?
How is a promoter sequence recognized?

answers.text: by transcription factors and RNA polymerase

qas.question: What results when genes have more than one promoter?

answers.text: messenger RNAs (mRNA) that differ in how far they extend in the 5' end

qas.question: What does a "strong" promoter sequence do?
What does a "weak" promoter sequence do?

answers.text: bind poorly and initiate transcription less frequently

context: Firstly, flanking the open reading frame, all genes contain <a0_0>a regulatory sequence<a0_0/> that is required for their expression. In order to be expressed, genes require a promoter sequence. The promoter is recognized and bound <a1_0>by transcription factors and RNA polymerase<a1_0/> to initiate transcription.:7.1 A gene can have more than one promoter, resulting in <a2_0>messenger RNAs (mRNA) that differ in how far they extend in the 5' end<a2_0/>. Promoter regions have a consensus sequence, however highly transcribed genes have "strong" promoter sequences that <a3_0>bind the transcription machinery well<a3_0/>, whereas others have "weak" promoters that <a4_0>bind poorly and initiate transcription less frequently<a4_0/>.:7.2 Eukaryotic promoter regions are much more complex and difficult to identify than prokaryotic promoters.:7.3
